Cairo- Work has begun to restore priceless Egyptian antiquities, including a statue of King Tutankhamun, damaged by looters amid anti-government in Cairo, antiquities chief Zahi Hawass said on Sunday. Seventy artefacts were damaged when looters broke into the world-famous Egyptian Museum, on the edge of Tahrir Square, focal point of an uprising against President Hosni Mubarak 's regime. "Restoration has started on the items, including on a statue of King Tutankhamun and a statute of King Akhenaten, Zahi Hawass told AFP. Looters had tried to break open a golden sarcophagus, hoping to find treasures inside, and some skeletons were also damaged, Zahi Hawass said. A gallery displaying King Tut's

"The whole time I was shooting, I was just thinking about seeing the student section," said Allen Iverson , who went 26-0 in Hartford while playing for UConn. This is a building in my mind that was always blue and white. It was the first time the Celtics played in Hartford since a preseason game in 1995. Prior to then, the Celtics played three regular season games a year in the arena formerly known as the Civic Center.
